abstracts.cdata!:
The Enterprise Institution Building Loan
            for Uzbekistan had the following ratings: the outcome was
            highly unsatisfactory, the sustainability was unlikely, the
            institutional development impact was modest, and the Bank
            and borrower performance were both unsatisfactory. Lessons
            learned from the project: Lack of government ownership
            undermines the effectiveness of even the best intentioned
            and designed operation. While risk taking during design
            should be encouraged, the Bank should not hesitate to draw
            back if an innovation fails. Technical Assistance is an
            expensive vehicle for policy dialogue when lack of political
            will rather than capacity is the key constraint on reform.
            There is a need, however, to reconsider how to best deliver
            technical assistance in environments such as Uzbekistan. In
            the context of uncertain or limited Government ownership,
            reluctance of the Borrower to restructure may reflect
            concern over internal reprisals rather than continued
            ownership and drive to deliver.

repnme.cdata!:
Uzbekistan - Enterprise Institutional
            Building Loan Project : amendments to the Loan Agreement

abstracts.cdata!:
The proposed amendments to the loan
            agreement of the Enterprise Institution Building Loan
            Project, entail narrowing of the original project objectives
            for the Privatization and Capital Market Components, with a
            focus on completing at least one successful sale of a large
            scale enterprise, by the end of the extended loanperiod,
            i.e. 3 1 December 2004, and, on completing ongoing technical
            assistance being rendered to the Securities Center within
            the Capital Markets Component. Despite risks identified in
            the Project Appraisal Document, with a more narrowly focused
            objectives however, and the detailed action plan which has
            been agreed with the Government, a reasonable basis has been
            established to manage the risks during completion of the
            remaining activities. The action plan, which will form the
            basis for  supervision, includes in respect to each of the
            activities, a) the steps to be undertaken, b) the
            responsible parties within the Government, and, c) the
            relevant return dates. Monthly progress reports will be
            submitted to the Bank, in addition to a more intensive
            supervision schedule. Investment banks, or other
            international advisers are assisting the Government in
            respect to all the activities. The proposed modifications
            comply with the Articles of Agreement, and it is recommended
            to approve the amendments to the Loan Agreement.

repnme.cdata!:
Uzbekistan - Enterprise Institution
            Building Loan Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Enterprise Institution Building
            Project 1) helps accelerate Uzbekistan's reform efforts
            in the enterprise sector; 2) facilitates the development and
            growth of a highly qualified domestic consulting industry;
            3) supports the efficient and transparent privatization of
            larger state enterprises; and 4) further develops capital
            markets. There are three components. Component 1,
            Post-Privatization Advisory Services, carries out diagnostic
            studies of enterprises that are candidates for financial
            assistance; prepares terms of reference for subsequent
            assistance, relating to rehabilitating and restructuring
            enterprises, including developing marketing strategy and
            quality management systems, providing partner search, and
            upgrading products to international standards, as well as
            implementing modern accounting, financial, and commercial
            management systems; and procures advisory services from
            outside consultants. Component 2, Case-by-Case
            Privatization, establishes an independent bureau to conduct
            transparent privatization of larger state enterprises.
            Component 3, Capital Markets Development, 1) helps develop
            the Securities Center, improving securities market
            regulation and investor protection; 2) bolsters the Stock
            Exchange and over-the-counter market participants to assist
            in supporting secondary trade in securities; 3) technically
            upgrades the National Depository; and 4) establishes the
            Securities Center as training coordinator for all market participants.

Uzbekistan - Enterprise Institution Building
            Loan Project
